extendedIngredients.name: beef
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1.5 kilos (3 1/3 pounds) sustainably raised beef for stewing (see note below), cut into 5-cm (2-inch) cubes
metaInformation: for stewing (see note below), cut into 5-cm (2-inch) cubes

extendedIngredients.name: black peppercorns
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1/4 teaspoon black peppercorns, crushed with the side of the blade
metaInformation: with the side of the blade

extendedIngredients.name: carrots
extendedIngredients.originalString: 450 grams (1 pound) small new carrots, trimmed (keep a small tuft of the stem) and halved lengthwise if on the thick side

extendedIngredients.name: fennel
extendedIngredients.originalString: 200 grams (7 ounces) baby fennel, trimmed and halved or quartered

extendedIngredients.name: fennel
extendedIngredients.originalString: 8 fennel stalks or 2 celery stalks, roughly chopped

extendedIngredients.name: green peas
extendedIngredients.originalString: 350 grams (3/4 pound, about 2 1/2 cups) shelled green peas

extendedIngredients.name: italian herb mix
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 teaspoon herbes de Provence or similar dried herb mix (basil, rosemary, oregano, savory, thyme...)

extendedIngredients.name: leek
extendedIngredients.originalString: leek greens from about 3 leeks, roughly chopped

extendedIngredients.name: shallots
extendedIngredients.originalString: 10 shallots, peeled and halved (leave in the root end so they will keep their shape)
metaInformation: (leave in the root end so they will keep their shape)

extendedIngredients.name: waxy potatoes
extendedIngredients.originalString: 450 grams (1 pound) waxy new potatoes, about 10 small ones

recipes.title: Springtime Pot-au-feu Beef Stew

winePairing.pairingText: Cabernet Sauvignon, Malbec, and Shiraz are my top picks for Beef Stew. These full-bodied red wines are the perfect accompaniment for hearty beef stew. One wine you could try is Gnarly Head Cabernet Sauvignon. It has 4.8 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 12 dollars.

productMatches.title: Gnarly Head Cabernet Sauvignon
productMatches.description: Gold Medal Winner: 2014 Los Angeles International Wine CompetitionGnarly Head 2012 Cabernet Sauvignon is King - big, gallant and powerful. This dark, bold Cabernet has solid tannins and jammy fruit, with aromas of black cherry, blackberry, freshly-cracked black peppercorn, violet and charred notes. On the palate, flavors of dense black fruit compote and currant followed by a trio of clove, spice and earth, lead to a generous, lingering finish.Try pairing this Cabernet with grilled lamb skewers, strong cheeses or a spaghetti Bolognese.

recipes.instructions: In a large soup pot or Dutch oven, place the meat and cover generously with cold water. Bring to a low simmer and cook for 1 hour, skimming the foam and scum regularly as they appear. After 1 hour, add the leek greens, carrot, fennel, garlic, onion, cloves, pepper, herbs, and salt. Add water to cover generously as needed, put the lid in place, and cook at a low simmer for another 3 hours. At this point, the meat should be fall-apart tender.Remove the meat and vegetables from the pot separately. Set the meat aside in a sealable container that you will place in the fridge once cool. (Some people throw away the vegetables, but I prefer to eat them that night, discarding any non-edible parts and eating them as is, or pureing them with a touch of strong mustard.) Strain the broth slowly into a large container, making sure you leave behind the sand-like, scummy bits at the bottom of the pot. Let cool on the counter then place in the fridge overnight.Put the potatoes in a medium pan and cover with cold water. Add salt, bring to a simmer, and cook, covered, until the potatoes are tender -- 10 to 15 minutes depending on their size. Drain and cut the potatoes in half lengthwise. Set aside.Remove the fat that has collected at the surface of the broth. Return to the cleaned pot, and add the new carrots, baby fennel, and shallots. Bring to a simmer and cook for 15 minutes, until very tender. Taste and adjust the seasoning.First, serve bowls of the broth with a sprinkle of chives and good crusty bread.While that's being enjoyed, add to the pot the reserved meat and potatoes, and the peas, and simmer for another 5 to 10 minutes, until the meat and potatoes are heated through and the peas are cooked.Serve the meat and vegetables in soup plates, ladling more broth over them, and place strong mustard and cornichons on the table.

steps.step: In a large soup pot or Dutch oven, place the meat and cover generously with cold water. Bring to a low simmer and cook for 1 hour, skimming the foam and scum regularly as they appear. After 1 hour, add the leek greens, carrot, fennel, garlic, onion, cloves, pepper, herbs, and salt.
Add water to cover generously as needed, put the lid in place, and cook at a low simmer for another 3 hours. At this point, the meat should be fall-apart tender.

Remove the meat and vegetables from the pot separately. Set the meat aside in a sealable container that you will place in the fridge once cool. (Some people throw away the vegetables, but I prefer to eat them that night, discarding any non-edible parts and eating them as is, or pureing them with a touch of strong mustard.) Strain the broth slowly into a large container, making sure you leave behind the sand-like, scummy bits at the bottom of the pot.
Let cool on the counter then place in the fridge overnight.
Put the potatoes in a medium pan and cover with cold water.
Add salt, bring to a simmer, and cook, covered, until the potatoes are tender -- 10 to 15 minutes depending on their size.
Drain and cut the potatoes in half lengthwise. Set aside.

Remove the fat that has collected at the surface of the broth. Return to the cleaned pot, and add the new carrots, baby fennel, and shallots. Bring to a simmer and cook for 15 minutes, until very tender. Taste and adjust the seasoning.First, serve bowls of the broth with a sprinkle of chives and good crusty bread.While that's being enjoyed, add to the pot the reserved meat and potatoes, and the peas, and simmer for another 5 to 10 minutes, until the meat and potatoes are heated through and the peas are cooked.
Serve the meat and vegetables in soup plates, ladling more broth over them, and place strong mustard and cornichons on the table.
